python, dialog to view html on Windows 10. do not use any framework.

In Python, you can use the `webbrowser` module to open a webpage in the default web browser. However, if you want to display HTML content within your own application without using any framework, you would typically use a web view control provided by a framework like Tkinter, PyQt, or wxPython. If you want to avoid using any framework and just use Python's standard library, you can use the `os` module to open the default web browser with the HTML content as a file. Here's an example of how you might do this: ```python import os import tempfile def view_html_in_browser(html_content): # Create a temporary file to hold the HTML content with tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile(delete=False, suffix='.html') as temp_file: # Write the HTML content to the temporary file temp_file.write(html_content.encode('utf-8')) temp_file.flush() # Get the path to the temporary file file_path = temp_file.name # Open the file in the default web browser os.startfile(file_path) # This will use the default application for .html files # Example usage: html_content = """ Page Title

This is a Heading

This is a paragraph.

""" view_html_in_browser(html_content) ``` This code will create a temporary HTML file, write the provided HTML content to it, and then open the file in the default web browser. Please note that this approach has limitations: - The HTML content must be self-contained and cannot reference external resources. - The user must have a web browser installed that can handle `.html` files. - The temporary file will not be deleted automatically after the browser has opened it, so you may want to add cleanup code to handle this. If you need more advanced features or a more integrated solution, you might want to consider using a web view control provided by a framework like Tkinter, PyQt, or wxPython. These frameworks provide components that can render HTML content within a window in your application.
